item.title: Coronavirus: Dominic Cummings to make statement on lockdown allegations
item.description: The PM's chief aide is facing calls from the opposition and some Tory MPs to resign over claims he flouted rules.

item.title: 'Virus could be here for year' so schools must open, says education secretary
item.description: But education secretary admits parents will be nervous about safety of children returning to school.

item.title: Brian May says he was 'very near death' after a heart attack
item.description: The Queen guitarist says he was "shocked" to discover he needed surgery and was "very near death".

item.title: New Zealand's PM stayed calm during an earthquake on live TV
item.description: New Zealand's PM Jacinda Ardern carries on a live TV interview as an earthquake hits parliament.

item.title: Coronavirus: Care home creates 'drive-through' visit
item.description: After careful planning, families were able to see the residents of one care home from the safety of their cars.

item.title: Prince Charles issues warning on the arts
item.description: The Prince says it is important that theatres and orchestras flourish after the coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sturgeon 'haunted' by virus impact on care homes
item.description: The first minister says the impact of coronavirus on care homes "will haunt a lot of us for a long time".

item.title: Coronavirus: Government draws up plan to rescue key firms
item.description: The government could aid strategically important firms affected by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: The South Korean Samsung protester living in the sky
item.description: Kim Yong-hee has spent nearly a year on a 20m traffic tower to protest against Samsung's zero-union policy.

item.title: Grenfell fears prevent timber building boom
item.description: Plans to reduce the height of wood-based properties contradicts advice to increase construction.

item.title: Coronavirus: Drivers plan to walk more to keep cleaner air of lockdown - survey
item.description: Survey suggests British motorists are ready to change their behaviour to protect the environment.

item.title: Hong Kong security law 'needed to tackle terrorism'
item.description: The territory's security chief says the controversial law will save it from violence.

item.title: UK turns to delivery cream teas during lockdown
item.description: Sweet treat deliveries see a surge in interest during lockdown, search data suggests.

item.title: How Coronavirus lockdown made a 'Zoom boom' generation
item.description: Digital transformation has advanced two years in just two months, says Microsoft.

item.title: Coronavirus: Americans flock to beaches on Memorial Day weekend
item.description: People are seen flouting restrictions on what is known in the US as the unofficial start of summer.

item.title: India coronavirus: The girl who cycled 1,200km to save her father
item.description: Jyoti Kumari, 15, took an arduous journey to save her father from hunger during the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown could ‘deal fatal blow’ to HIV in the UK
item.description: Lockdown has created a unique opportunity to cut HIV transmissions in the UK, says a major sexual health clinic.

item.title: Coronavirus: Creative solutions to social distancing
item.description: As some lockdown restrictions ease, countries are finding inventive ways to keep people safe in public spaces.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown brought a village closer together
item.description: A huge volunteer effort has brought Piddlehinton's 500 residents closer together.

item.title: The Metro Manila priests fighting coronavirus with the cross
item.description: Catholic priests in Metro Manila are risking their lives to serve their poverty-stricken community.

item.title: Life-sized Crystal Palace Park dinosaur sculpture damaged
item.description: The Grade I-listed Megalosaurus statue has been in Crystal Palace Park since the Victorian era.

item.title: 'I left my campervan in Argentina'
item.description: Thousands of van-driving nomads were living the dream - until the coronavirus pandemic brought them to a sudden halt.

item.title: Capt Tom donations: What is the £33m actually being spent on?
item.description: The money raised is not being used to buy core equipment - instead it is being used in other ways.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak: Five ways Europe is easing lockdown
item.description: Jogging in a Madrid park, having a Czech beer, taking a Greek ferry - Europe is opening up more.

item.title: The man who sells 700 million sandwiches a year
item.description: Patrick Coveney, is the boss of the UK's largest sandwich maker of pre-packaged sandwiches.

item.title: Coronavirus: The unseen key workers keeping things going
item.description: Our toilets still flush and our homes still have power in lockdown thanks to these key workers.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak: Caribbean tourism struggles as visitors stay home
item.description: Tourism is vital to the Caribbean but visitors are absent amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: What did he do during lockdown?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser is accused of breaking lockdown rules - what do we know so far?

item.title: Women's Super League & Women's Championship seasons ended immediately
item.description: The Women's Super League and Women's Championship seasons are ended immediately, but sporting outcomes are still to be decided.

item.title: 'Don't tell me you're a professional club when you pay 80 quid a week' - Strachan questions Scottish set-up
item.description: Former Scotland boss Gordon Strachan believes too many of the country's senior clubs are not professional enough.

item.title: Euros Game of the Century: Last 16 - vote for the greatest match since 2000
item.description: Thirty-two classic European Championship fixtures facing off in a knockout tournament - you decide the winner.

item.title: Woods & Manning beat Brady & Mickelson in $20m charity match
item.description: Tiger Woods, Tom Brady, Peyton Manning and Phil Mickelson raise $20m for coronavirus relief efforts in The Match: Champions for Charity.

item.title: What your gym could look like when it re-opens after coronavirus lockdown
item.description: UK Active is working on a 'framework' for how our gyms could re-open - here's what they could look like.

item.title: Saracens' Kruis to move to Japan at end of season
item.description: England and Saracens lock George Kruis will join Japanese Top League side Panasonic Wild Knights on a one-year contract at the end of the season.

item.title: Could you have to pay your bank to save money?
item.description: As countries take extreme measures keep the economy afloat, could we see negative interest rates?

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions in England?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on caring for children during lockdown?
item.description: A look at the guidance as Downing Street backs Dominic Cummings over his 260-mile lockdown trip.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work and is my data safe?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Changes have been announced to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe are takeaways and supermarket deliveries?
item.description: If coronavirus can be transferred on to surfaces, what are the risks of buying food?

item.title: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can children catch and pass on coronavirus?
item.description: BBC's Health Correspondent Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where do governments borrow money?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Where are cases still rising?
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: What it does to the body
item.description: What is it like to have the coronavirus, how will it affect you and how is it treated?

item.title: Coronavirus: Will schools be able to reopen in June?
item.description: There are differing views on whether English schools should reopen in June.

item.title: Coronavirus: Is Latin America the next epicentre?
item.description: New cases have been rising sharply in Brazil and Mexico, along with other countries in the region.

item.title: Coronavirus: How much will it cost the UK?
item.description: The pandemic will cost the government hundreds of billions of pounds. Where will it all come from?

item.title: Coronavirus: Should I defer going to university? And other questions
item.description: Can you start driving lessons again? and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Why can some of us meet six people?
item.description: Different policies are down to a number of factors, including geography, science and politics, experts say.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The number at the heart of the decision whether to lift lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus update: What are the symptoms of coronavirus?
item.description: The BBC’s Laura Foster explains how you can recognise the symptoms of coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: For the first time, people in England are being advised to wear face coverings in some situations.

item.title: Coronavirus information: What should I do now?
item.description: Step-by-step, what to do to help prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will I be able to go on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus and hydroxychloroquine: What do we know?
item.description: President Trump says he takes the drug as a preventative measure. But what do we know about its effectiveness?

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: We answer some of the big questions about vaccines and how long one for coronavirus could take.

item.title: Coronavirus symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: Loss of taste and smell have been added to the UK's list of coronavirus symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: When did care homes go into lockdown?
item.description: Many thousands of care home residents have died from coronavirus, but when were key decisions made?

item.title: Coronavirus: How long does it take to recover?
item.description: Recovery from Covid-19 can be a lengthy process, depending on how seriously people get the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how are other European countries reopening after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: How will the Covid-19 alert system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is to be ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Am I allowed to move house?
item.description: The easing of lockdown will affect those who want to buy or sell a home, or rent somewhere new, in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Police across the UK now have wide-ranging powers to help fight the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: How reopened schools in Denmark keep children safely apart
item.description: What's it like in a school that has re-opened? Denmark and Germany show how it might look.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: "Bubbles" of people we can meet safely may form part of the plans to ease lockdown in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does lockdown easing 'follow the science'?
item.description: Why is England pressing ahead with plans to ease lockdown rules ahead of the rest of the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: How do I travel to work now?
item.description: Some people are being encouraged to go back to work, but how will they get there?

item.title: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.
